data.text: Mold In Sleeping Pad

Mold in sleeping pad I bought a new Therm-a-rest last year and only used it for 2 tours. In February I slept on it for a week and then packed it away with my other outdoor gear. It seemed completely dry and I have always used the air pump bag to blow it up. Nevertheless some moisture must have gotten in there and 2 months later when I wanted to use it again it bloomed in all colors - black, white and red. Almost the complete surface is colored but I think the actual mold is inside. Is there any way to save the sleeping pad?
I would toss it.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: White vinegar, slosh it around inside , then the fun bit trying to dry it!
data.author: J Darren Trevan

data.text: Mold spores can be dangerous. I wouldn't risk it personally.
data.author: Matthew Adams

data.text: Mold spores can be easily removed. He's not inhaling his sleeping pad. üòÑ
data.author: Trey Freeman

data.text: I do when I get very drunk.
data.author: Matthew Adams

data.text: Bin it. It's only a Thermarest Neo after all.
data.author: Il Padrone

data.text: Not worth the risk. But if you must. A vinegar/ water mix through the valve should do it. Let soak for a day or so. Then do mutliple cycles of inflate, leave in the sun for a bit and then deflate. Make sure you do your best not to breath in the spores. Also, even if you do manage to nuke the mold. The discolouration will surely stay on.
data.author: Wacky Gochoco

data.text: for mold, you should use hydrogen peroxyde.

data.text: might be a good idea. I‚Äôm just not sure how the coatings on the inside will react to it.
data.author: Wacky Gochoco

data.text: never fungus and acid! Fungus loves pH <7. 9 is ideal
data.author: Sven Lars Felten

data.text: Get a new one and when you store it leave it open and in a dry environment.
data.author: Jerry Sorensen

data.text: mine are all stored hanging with the valve open. If I come from somewhere particularly wet, I‚Äôll do a few inflate/short sun exposure/ deflate cycles to try and get as much moisture out before storing.
data.author: Wacky Gochoco

data.text: Well I guess it's time I'd start tossing in beads of desiccant inside sleeping pad üò´
data.author: Nico Lasaca

data.text: Send the pix to thermarest and ask for their advice? It makes me wonder what the inside of my Thermarests look like after me having blown into them for literally years. Probably best that I don't know. ;-P
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: I think the trick too prevent it is to not store it rolled up in its sleeve
data.author: Tom Ooms

data.text: I store our Exped Synmats rolled up ALL the time. However they are only filled with the in-built hand-pump, not by mouth. This has always been a risk with Thermarests, and they always advocated that the old Thermarest insulated pads be stored open for this reason, to reduce moisture and related issues.
data.author: Il Padrone

data.text: same for sleeping bags and actually anything that rolls up tightly
data.author: Tom Ooms

data.text: pump will help ofcourse
data.author: Tom Ooms

data.text: like I said, our Synmats are always stored rolled up and in their sack. Sleeping bags (especially down ones) on the other hand need to be stored open and hung, or in large sacks to prevent down being crushed and damaged through compression.
data.author: Il Padrone

data.text: Brush, soap with a bit of bleach and get scrubbing
data.author: Tim Rodriguez

data.text: I think that's a goner.
data.author: Bridget McGill

data.text: Dump it, that‚Äôs dangerous!
data.author: Paul Robert Smeaton

data.text: Why are people saying it‚Äôs dangerous? Unsightly and a bit minging but not like you go inhaling from the mat is it?!
data.author: Tom England

data.text: and .. it is on the inside ... Please do not inhale your airpad
data.author: Tom Ooms

data.text: if you deflate it every morning in your tent then you are definitely inhaling mould spores. Mould can grow in the body - I have a friend who is debilitated by it and always will be.
data.author: Karen Robyn

data.text: Never thought about it you breathe in the spores wen deflating in the tent . The ultra light doesn‚Äôt inflate by itself and after six years of use (14 months bike tour) the laminate inside came lose from moisture. But the gave me a new one and happy about that.
data.author: Yan Stam

data.text: It must have been stored wet. I am and have been using the same for many years. After many storages too, I am getting these symptoms only in a limited area around the valve, and because I am inflating it with the mouth! Never been able to clean it completely, but it has not been a problem.
data.author: Jean-Marc Combret

data.author: Joeby Daff

data.text: You can send it to me and I will dispose of it at the toxic sleeping pad department.
data.author: Does Not Expire

data.text: The same people saying dump it probably use moldy water bottles all the time lol. Mold is only dangerous if you inhale it so unless you plan to put your face in it and do some deep breathing you're fine. Pour undiluted white vinegar into a spray bottle. Spray it directly onto the moldy surface. Let the vinegar sit for at least an hour. Repeat if you're paranoid.
data.author: Trey Freeman

data.text: No, the first sign of any growth in my bottles is when I toss it. It's also why I don't use dark colored bottles.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: fungus loves acid. pH should be around 9 not <7. You achieve the opposite
data.author: Sven Lars Felten

data.text: that's fine, but unnecessary.
data.author: Trey Freeman

data.text: You should probably do more research before posting nonsense. Vinegar has literally been used for thousands of years as a disinfectant and kills 82% of known household molds.
data.author: Trey Freeman

data.text: yep maybe but acid does not work against fungus. Look at industrial applications e.g. in food- (surface fungus management) or metalworking-industry (emulsion management to control fungus) All cleaners are alcaline. If you still do not believe google what pH environment kills fungus...
data.author: Sven Lars Felten

data.text:
fungus is not necessarily mold. "Research has found that vinegar is effective at preventing mold growth on fruit and at removing some common household molds, but it isn‚Äôt effective at killing every type of mold." https://www.healthline.com/health/does-vinegar-kill-mold#does-it-work
Does Vinegar Kill Mold and Mildew? What Works, What Doesn‚Äôt
healthline.com
data.author: Il Padrone

data.text: Return it to There-A-Rest - they have a very good service department from what I heard....
data.author: Klaus-Dieter Jungermann

data.text: Definitely contact ThermRest. We have had excellent customer service from them. 99% chance they will replace it no questions asked. BTW, be sure to let them know if you need a certain shape (we required rectangular for our sleeping bag system). Cheers!
data.author: Jeannine Lancaster

data.text: Contact ThermARest - I had a similar situation, always took good care of my mat, returned it to thermarest, they investigated and sent me a new one.
data.author: Margriet Schuring

data.text: Next time use a pump sack or the micro pump to minimize blowing moist lung air into the pad.
data.author: Richard Mead

data.text: Soak them in bleach water may be more effective than vinegar
data.author: Bang Dinh Nhan

data.text: Put some anti mold liquid containing chloride and dip it in for 24 hrs. Then give it a wash. It may lose colouring but mould will be gone.
data.author: Brij Patel

data.text: Easy. Spray with concrobium (available at hardware store). Let it sit for several minutes. Wipe to like-new cleanness. You can make a similar mold killer with oxy-clean. Concrobium is what is used to remove house mold. It is non-toxic for the environment as it breaks down to h2o and o2.
data.author: Jarod Cassada

data.text: Just dont you it..
data.author: Anchica Chobot

data.text: Sure it‚Äôs grand ‚Ä¶.
data.author: Niall Diamond

data.text: I surely am worried about mine now... It's been stored away (rolled up and in its sleeve üò±üò±) for about 2 years+... And I am planning a long distance hike this summer. HELP!!
data.author: Fabrizio Ortogni

data.text: Wash it use it.....
data.author: Mik Murray

data.text: Do not roll up your sleeping pad when you are not camping. I put it between my closet and the wall. Down sleeping bag the same but in a large bag so that down can air
data.author: Laurence Aubry

data.text: Save it from what?
data.author: Chris Juden

data.text: I think any cleaner liquid you put inside will stay in there and never get dry. UV light from the sun might help. If it's still holding air maybe you can just use it, like it is.
data.author: Marc Mallary

data.text: Either vinegar, 70% alcohol or hydrogen peroxide (I think it was 3%) are natural ways of getting rid of it.
data.author: Christiane Hoyer

data.text: Store it in the freezer.
data.author: Kaja Curry

data.text: Reminds me of flats I've stayed in! Definitely bin it if you can, not worth it personally. But if you have to save it, then I'd say bleach, it'll either save it or it won't, and at least you'll be rid of the mold and maybe a matt you were gonna chuck anyway.
data.author: Jack Grundles

data.text: My eight years old ThermaRest NeoAir is more then fine. And has been use in many different dry and wet context. It would be interesting how the mould could grow into your mattress! üçÄüçÄ As mention above : ask ThermaRest what their best solution would be ! üçÄüçÄüåà

data.text: Only unroll it after dark so you can't see it.
data.author: Clay Pardue

data.text: On a completely selfish note, i blow up our thermostat mattresses using a bag of air, so don't blow up myself. Occasionally a few puffs just to top up. I deflate every morning in the tent. As cycling around the world for the next few years, im just wondering if should be safer to either deflate outside or let my husband do it ü§îüòâ. Never occurred to me it could be an issue. Sorry about your mattress, id ask the manufacturer for advice. Hope good results.

data.text: I would think some bleach would fix it

data.text: No
